titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Vladimir Korvin-Piotrovskii Papers
titlestmt.author: by Lisa Conathan

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:13

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection contains correspondence, writings, photographs, scrapbooks and an audio recording that document the literary careers of Vladimir Korvin-Piotrovskii and IUrii Ofrosimov, the professional life of Italian sculptor Italo Griselli and the activities of the Russian expatriate Berlin Poets' Club.

langmaterial.language: Materials in Russian, English and French.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The IUrii Ofrosimov Papers (Series IV) were sent to Nina Korvin-Piotrovskaia from Ofrosimov's widow Dorothea Ofrosimov-Voegeli in 1968.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 14-15: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Vladimir Korvin-Piotrovskii Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Vladimir Korvin-Piotrovskii Papers. Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: When the Beinecke Library received this collection, the notebooks had been numbered (likely by Nina Korvin-Piotrovskaia). A notebook labeled #16, with the inscription " Beatriche , rewritten by hand not long before [his] death," is not present in the collection.
Folder 151 in box 8 is unused. Original reel-to-reel audiotape is now housed in box 14. Restricted fragile material.

p.ref: G. Rosimov (IUrii Ofrosimov) Papers, GEN MSS 312

bioghist.head: Vladimir L'vovich Korvin-Piotrovskii, 1892-1966
bioghist.p: Vladimir L'vovich Korvin-Piotrovskii was born May 15, 1892 in Kiev. His place of birth is sometimes identified as the Ukranian town of Bila Tserkva, where Korvin-Piotrovskii spent much of his childhood. During Word War I, Korvin-Piotrovskii served in the White Army as an artillery officer. After being taken prisoner and barely escaping execution, he crossed through Poland and made his way to Berlin around 1920.

In Berlin, Korvin-Piotrovskii became active in the Russian emigre literary community. There he met IUrii Ofrosimov and Vladimir Sirin (Nabokov). He also became involved with the Berlin Poets' Club, a group of Russian emigre poets founded by Mikhail Gorlin. In addition to Ofrosimov, Korvin-Piotrovskii and Sirin, members included Raisa Blokh, Nina Korvin-Piotrovskaia (née Kaplun), Vera Nabokov, and Sofiia Pregel'.

Vladimir and Nina Korvin-Piotrovskii left Germany before World War II began. Nina Korvin-Piotrovskaia worked at the French Embassy in Berlin and they were able to travel to Paris with embassy staff. During World War II, Korvin-Piotrovskii was active in the French Resistance movement. He was arrested and imprisoned for approximately eight months in 1944. His fellow prisoners included the French writer André Frossard, whose memoir La maison des otages documents this time period.

Vladimir and Nina Korvin-Piotrovskii were close friends with Italo and Leila Griselli and visited them many times in Italy. Italo Griselli, a sculptor, made busts of both Vladimir and Nina Korvin-Piotrovskii.

In 1961 the family moved to Los Angeles, California, where Vladimir Korvin-Piotrovskii died on April 2, 1966 and Nina Korvin-Piotrovskaia died in 1975. They had one son, Andre De Korvin, born in 1935.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Papers document the literary work of twentieth-century Russian poet and writer Vladimir L'vovich Korvin-Piotrovskii as well as the emigre circles in which he worked in Berlin and Paris. Correspondence (Series I) dates predmoninantly from the 1950s and 1960s and relates to publications and literary criticism. There are also several letters to Nina Korvin-Piotrovskaia about her husband's writings and publications. Writings (Series II) include holograph drafts of many of Korvin-Piotrovskii's works as well as corrected and annotated printed versions. There is also one audio recording of Korvin-Piotrovskii reading his poetry. Of particular interest is a scrapbook from the Berlin Poets' Club that documents membership, poetry readings, correspondence, minutes and meeting notes. Papers relating to Korvin-Piotrovskii's service in the French Resistance and imprisonment at Fort Montluc can be found in Personal Papers (Series III).

The Papers also contain material from IUrii Ofrosimov and Italo Griselli, both friends of Korvin-Piotrovskii. The IUrii Ofrosimov Papers (Series IV) document the collaboration of Ofrosimov and Korvin-Piotrovskii on children's stories, using the pseudonyms Chika Bura and Chika Dzhura. The Italo Griselli Correspondence (Series V) documents the communications of early twentieth-century Italian artists and architects, particularly those involved in the Futurism movement.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Papers are organized into five series: I. Correspondence, 1920-1973. II. Writings, 1928-1966. III. Personal Papers, 1944-1958. IV. IUrii Ofrosimov Papers, 1939-1962. V. Italo Griselli Correspondence, 1899-1953.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into three subseries: Vladimir Korvin-Piotrovskii, Nina Korvin-Piotrovskaia and Third Party. Correspondence within each subseries is arranged alphabetically. Correspondence is also filed elsewhere in the collection, as detailed in the series description.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I contains correspondence between Vladimir Korvin-Piotrovskii and his literary colleagues, most of which is incoming and dates from 1945 to 1965. The Series also includes correspondence of Nina Korvin-Piotrovskaia, primarily related to her husband's literary affairs in the years after his death. These include letters related to the publication of Pozdnii Gost' . In addition, there are three third party letters, two of which were laid in to Italo Griselli's scrapbook of correspondence.

Correspondence related to the publication of Pozdnii Gost' is filed at the end of the Nina Korvin-Piotrovskaia subseries. Correspondence of Korvin-Piotrovskii can also be found in his scrapbooks (see Notebook 22and Notebook 23 in Series II). Correspondence of the Berlin Poets' Club is in a scrapbook (see Notebook 31 in Series II). Correspondence related to Korvin-Piotrovskii's imprisonment at Fort Montluc is in Series III.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Series is organized into five subseries: Notebooks and Scrapbooks, Poetry, Short Stories, Articles, and Writings of Others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains drafts and printed versions of many of Korvin-Piotrovskii's works, including the long dramatic poem Beatriche , material for the volume Pozdnii Gost' , and critical essays. Scrapbooks include clippings and correspondence, most related to Korvin-Piotrovskii's publications. There is also one audio recording of Korvin-Piotrovskii reading his poetry.

Of particular interest is Notebook 31 (scrapbook). The scrapbook documents the Poets' Club of Berlin, a club for Russian emigre poets that met from 1928 to 1933. The book also contains photographs from later dates. Vladimir and Nina Korvin-Piotrovskii took the scrapbook with them when they fled Berlin prior to World War II. The Berlin Poets' Club was founded by Mikhail Gorlin and many of the notes, sketches and manuscripts in the scrapbook are authored by him.

Throughout the series, writings include drafts and notes in Nina Korvin-Piotrovskaia's hand. These indicate that she transcribed or edited works both before and after Vladimir Korvin-Piotrovskii's death.

Arrangement of the notebooks and scrapbooks largely preserves the order in which the material was received by the Beinecke Library. They were numbered (likely by Nina Korvin-Piotrovskaia) and these numbers are retained in the folder titles.
Poetry is grouped according to the three major geographic locations in which Korvin-Piotrovskii wrote: Berlin, Paris and California.
Children's stories that Korvin-Piotrovskii wrote with IUrii Ofrosimov are filed in Series IV.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Notebooks are arranged by number. Discontinuous numbering is due to the fact that some material (such as correspondence) is now filed in the other subseries or series. Notebook #16 is not present in the collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Writings in notebooks and scrapbooks are holograph drafts unless otherwise noted

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Clippings include reviews and articles about Korvin-Piotrovskii and his work. Writings include a corrected typescript of a lecture by A. Prokopenko, corrected typescripts of articles by IUrii Ofrosimov and a manuscript excerpt from Russkaia Literatura v Izgnanii .

Correspondents include Aleksandr Avdeich [Adelboden?], N. Andreeva, Dmitrii Klenovskii (excerpts of letters to IUrii Ofrosimov), V. Mamchenko, IUrii Ofrosimov, Aleksis Rannit, Veidle, Kirill Elita-Vil'chkovskii and unidentified correspondents.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Letters related to the publication of Pozdnii Gost' , found in two packets at pages 77 and 82, have been interfiled in Series I, Nina Korvin-Piotrovskaia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Clippings include reviews and articles about Korvin-Piotrovskii and his work. Correspondents include Ekaterina Tauber and unidentified correspondents.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The scrapbook contains notes, drawings, correspondence, poetry and photographs. The notes include bylaws, decrees, membership information and minutes of meetings of the Poets' Club. The drawings (most by Gorlin) include many that are humorous or caricatures (for example "Gumilev in Africa"). The correspondence is from club members or close associates. Poetry includes holograph manuscripts (some signed) by Raisa Blokh, Mikhail Gorlin, Vladimir Korvin-Piotrovskii, IUrii Ofrosimov and unidentified authors. Subjects of the photographs include N. A. Berdiaev, S. S. Berdiaeva, Aleksandr Ginger, Georgii Ivanov, Irina Odoevtseva, Anna Prismanova, E. Rabinovich, Evgeniia Rapp and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a brochure promoting the recitation of Mary Schneider-Braillard and a program for an evening of songs by Lori Cornell

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Poetry is arranged roughly chronologically and organized under three geographic headings (Berlin, Paris, California). Poetry from unidentified time periods is filed at the end of the subseries under the heading Other Poems.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III contains papers related to Korvin-Piotrovskii's participation in the French Resistance (which document recognition by the French government), photographs and other personal papers.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The papers in Series IV were sent from Dorthea Ofrosimov-Voegeli to Nina Korvin-Piotrovskaia on December 5, 1968.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series IV is organized into three subseries: Correspondence, Stories and Critical Articles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This Series contains correspondence and writings of IUrii Ofrosimov. The small amount of correspondence is all outgoing and relates to literary topics. The writings include children's stories that Ofrosimov wrote with Vladimir Korvin-Piotrovskii. Some of the stories are signed with the pseudonyms Chika Bura and Chika Dzhura. The critical articles relate chiefly to twentieth-century Russian poetry.

did.unittitle: Letter to the editor of an unidentified newspaper
Unidentified letter about a position of Russian Lecturer

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Stories are arranged alphabetically by title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: All stories are holograph drafts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Critical Articles are arranged alphabetically by title or subject.

did.unittitle: Alekseeva, Lidiia, article on, typescript, corrected
Ivanov, Georgii, article on, typescript, corrected
Korvin-Piotrovskii, Vladimir, article on, typescript, corrected
Russian Paris School, article on, typescript, corrected

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series V is arranged alphabetically. The contents of this series were removed from a scrapbook in order to prevent damage to the letters and facilitate research use.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The correspondence is largely unrelated to the rest of the Vladimir Korvin-Piotrovskii Collection and probably was given to Korvin-Piotrovskii because of his personal friendship with Griselli.

Italo Griselli's correspondence consists chiefly of postcards from other Italian artists and writers of the early twentieth century, including several Futurists. There are also a few postcards from Latvia signed by several people including Valdemars Dambergs and Julijs Sprogis. Some unrelated papers were formerly laid in to the scrapbook. These were likely not Griselli's but have been filed at the end of this Series, as has the scrapbook itself.
Two letters formerly laid in to the scrapbook have been interfiled in Series I, Third Party.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Box 14 contains fragile originals. The material is arranged in folder order and may be accessed only with the permission of the appropriate curator. A reference copy of the audio recording has been substituted in the main files for reference use.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Box 15 contains fragile originals. The material is arranged in folder order and may be accessed only with the permission of the appropriate curator. Preservation photocopies have been substituted in the main files for reference use.
